title: Could we create dark matter? - Rolf Landua

multiple-choice.question: What is dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of star that is invisible to the human eye.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of galaxy that is unknown to scientists.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of matter that makes up 85% of the universe, but is unknown in composition.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of planet that is not yet discovered.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of telescope used to observe the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of microscope used to study the properties of matter.

options.label: C
options.text: A 27 kilometer-long particle collider used to accelerate protons to near the speed of light.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of computer used to process data.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two proton beams collide at the LHC?

options.label: A
options.text: The protons pass through each other without any significant outcome.

options.label: B
options.text: The protons combine to form a single particle.

options.label: C
options.text: The protons collide and produce thousands of new particles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the detectors surrounding the collision points at the LHC?

options.label: A
options.text: To observe the collision points visually.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the energy of the particles produced in the collision.

options.label: C
options.text: To gather information on the particles produced in the collision, including their trajectory, electrical charge, and energy.

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy the particles produced in the collision.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Higgs boson?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of particle that is thought to be responsible for giving mass to other particles.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of particle that is thought to be responsible for holding the universe together.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of particle that is thought to be responsible for the expansion of the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of particle that is thought to be responsible for the formation of galaxies.

multiple-choice.question: How did scientists determine the presence of the Higgs boson?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing its direct interaction with other particles.

options.label: B
options.text: By observing its decay into other particles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "bump" in the graph that indicates the presence of the Higgs boson?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates the presence of a new particle.

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates the presence of a known particle.

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates the presence of a background event.

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates the absence of a particle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge in detecting dark matter at the LHC?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too difficult to accelerate protons to the required speed.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too difficult to detect the particles produced in the collision.

options.label: C
options.text: It is too rare to produce the particles that make up dark matter.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too expensive to operate the LHC.

title: The rise and fall of the Berlin Wall - Konrad H. Jarausch

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred in the early hours of August 13, 1961, in Berlin and its surroundings?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of the Federal Republic of Germany.

options.label: B
options.text: The beginning of the construction of the Berlin Wall.

options.label: C
options.text: The division of Germany into East and West.

options.label: D
options.text: The end of World War II.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the division of Germany after World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: The Soviet Union's desire to expand its territory.

options.label: B
options.text: The Western powers' disagreement with the Soviet Union over their visions for post-war Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: The economic differences between East and West Germany.

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of the Nazi party.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the secret police in East Germany that monitored citizens for any hint of disloyalty?
What was the name of the treaty signed in 1972 that recognized East Germany pragmatically while West Germany retained its hope for eventual reunification?
What event occurred on the evening of November 9, 1989, that marked the beginning of the end of the division of Germany?

options.label: B
options.text: The East German government announced that it would make travel permits easier to obtain.

options.label: C
options.text: The Soviet Union invaded East Germany.

options.label: D
options.text: The West German government announced that it would withdraw from Berlin.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the mass demonstrations for free travel and demands for democracy in the Eastern Bloc regimes in the late 1980s?

options.label: A
options.text: The Eastern Bloc regimes became more repressive.

options.label: B
options.text: The Eastern Bloc regimes became more liberal.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the reunification of Germany in October 1990?

options.label: A
options.text: The Eastern Bloc regimes were re-established.

options.label: B
options.text: The Soviet Union expanded its territory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Berlin Wall today?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a symbol of the division of Germany.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a reminder of the importance of building walls.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a reminder that any barriers we put up to impede freedom, we can also break down.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a reminder of the rise of the Nazi party.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the death strip in the Berlin Wall?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a buffer zone between East and West Berlin.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a no-man's land where people could cross freely.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a 100-meter area where guards were stationed to shoot anyone attempting to cross.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a area where people could exercise their rights.

multiple-choice.question: How many people died while attempting to escape from East Germany between 1961 and 1989?

title: Why a total solar eclipse is such a big deal

multiple-choice.question: What is a solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: When the Earth's shadow falls on the moon.

options.label: B
options.text: When the moon's shadow falls on the surface of Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: When the Earth and moon are aligned with the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: When the sun and moon are in the same position in the sky.

multiple-choice.question: What is a total solar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: A partial eclipse where the moon only covers a small part of the sun.

options.label: B
options.text: A total eclipse where the moon precisely covers the sun from the vantage point of some place on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: An annular eclipse where the moon is too far away to fully block the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: A lunar eclipse where the Earth's shadow falls on the moon.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we get eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the moon's orbit is in line with Earth's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the moon's orbit is tilted about 5 degrees.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are two points where the moon's orbit crosses the sun's plane, called nodes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the Earth and moon are in the same position in the sky.

multiple-choice.question: What is the totality of a lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: A short period of time where the moon is completely covered by the Earth's shadow.

options.label: B
options.text: A long period of time where the moon is completely covered by the Earth's shadow.

options.label: C
options.text: A period of time where the moon is partially covered by the Earth's shadow.

options.label: D
options.text: A period of time where the moon is not covered by the Earth's shadow.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the moon often turn red during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the shorter, bluer wavelengths of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the moon's surface is reflecting the red light from the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon is absorbing the red light from the Earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: How often do we get total solar eclipses?
Why do eclipse chasers travel all over the world to witness total solar eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they want to see the beauty of the eclipse.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they want to experience the scientific significance of the eclipse.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they want to be in the path of the shadow.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they want to be in the same position as the sun and moon.

multiple-choice.question: What is the moon's distance from Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: It is constant and does not change.

options.label: B
options.text: It is increasing by more than 3 cm per year.

options.label: C
options.text: It is decreasing by more than 3 cm per year.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not changing at all.

multiple-choice.question: How will the frequency of total solar eclipses change in the far future?
Why did Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong leave mirrors on the moon in 1969?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a pathway for the moon's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the moon's distance from Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new form of communication.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new form of transportation.

title: Will the ocean ever run out of fish? - Ayana Elizabeth Johnson and Jennifer Jacquet

multiple-choice.question: What has happened to the cod population off Canada's East Coast?
What technologies are used in modern industrial fishing to guide factory ships towards schools of fish?

options.label: A
options.text: Radar, sonar, helicopters, and spotter planes.

options.label: B
options.text: GPS, satellite imaging, and underwater cameras.

options.label: C
options.text: Drones, fishing nets, and fishing lines.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with catching deep water fish like the Patagonian toothfish?

options.label: C
options.text: They don't reproduce until they're at least ten years old.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not good for the environment.

multiple-choice.question: Why is shark fin soup considered a delicacy in China and Vietnam?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the fin is the most profitable part of the shark.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is good for the environment.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the world's fish populations are overfished?
What is the main impact of wild shrimp fishing on ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: It disrupts or destroys seafloor habitats.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the population of wild shrimp.

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases the population of wild shrimp.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on ecosystems.

multiple-choice.question: What is a way to give fish a break and let them recover?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the amount of fishing.

options.label: C
options.text: By setting limits on how, when, where, and how much fishing occurs.

multiple-choice.question: What can consumers do to help reduce wasteful practices like shark finning?

options.label: B
options.text: Boycott fishing industries that engage in shark finning.

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the demand for shark fin soup.

multiple-choice.question: Why is international collaboration needed to end overfishing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because fish care about our borders.

options.label: B
options.text: Because fish don't care about our borders.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we need to end overfishing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is good for the economy.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is good for the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: Because ecosystems, food security, jobs, economies, and coastal cultures depend on it.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not a problem.

title: When is water safe to drink? - Mia Nacamulli

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why one out of ten people in the world can't be sure that their water is clean and safe to drink?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of access to clean water sources

options.label: B
options.text: Inadequate sanitation, poor protection of drinking water sources, and improper hygiene

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of awareness about water safety

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main parts of a proper treatment process for water?
What is the purpose of the sedimentation step in the treatment process?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove contaminants from the water

options.label: B
options.text: To kill off pathogens in the water

options.label: C
options.text: To allow heavier particles to sink to the bottom

options.label: D
options.text: To filter out particles from the water

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the disinfection step in the treatment process?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove contaminants from the water

options.label: B
options.text: To kill off pathogens in the water

options.label: C
options.text: To filter out particles from the water

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the taste of the water

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern with the use of chlorine in water treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not effective in killing off pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: It has potentially harmful chemical byproducts

options.label: C
options.text: It is too expensive to use

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the long-term health effects of water contamination?

options.label: A
options.text: Cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neurological disease

options.label: B
options.text: Miscarriage, birth defects, and respiratory disease

options.label: C
options.text: Skin problems, eye problems, and gastrointestinal disease

multiple-choice.question: How can you tell if the water you have access to is drinkable?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking for a clear color and no odor

options.label: B
options.text: By testing the water with a water testing kit

options.label: C
options.text: By checking for turbidity, trace organic compounds, and heavy metals

options.label: D
options.text: By looking for a label that says "safe to drink"

multiple-choice.question: What is point-of-use treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: A treatment process that uses ionization to lower mineral content

options.label: D
options.text: A treatment process that uses adsorption filtration to remove contaminants

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of point-of-use treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a portable and easy-to-install solution

options.label: D
options.text: It is a widely available solution

multiple-choice.question: Why is clean water a precious and often scarce commodity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not widely available

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is not essential for human survival

options.label: C
options.text: Because nearly 800 million people still don't have regular access to it

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not needed for daily life

title: Why is the very hungry caterpillar so dang hungry?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary job of adult butterflies?

options.label: A
options.text: To lay eggs and store protein for the next generation.

options.label: B
options.text: To fly and migrate to warmer climates.

options.label: D
options.text: To eat and store food for the winter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main source of protein for caterpillars?

What is the purpose of a caterpillar's antennae?

options.label: A
options.text: It hardens and becomes a chrysalis.

options.label: B
options.text: It softens and becomes a pupa.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same and doesn't change.

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears and is replaced by a new skin.

What is the purpose of a butterfly's proboscis?
How long do monarch caterpillars grow in two weeks?
What is the name of the plant that monarch caterpillars eat?
What is the name of the series that Lauren mentions at the end of the video?

title: Will we ever be able to teleport? - Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: Sending a physical object from one place to another instantly.

options.label: B
options.text: Transferring information about a physical object from one place to another.

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a duplicate of a physical object in a different location.

options.label: D
options.text: Destroying a physical object in one location and recreating it in another.

multiple-choice.question: What is the uncertainty principle in quantum physics?

options.label: A
options.text: The principle that all particles have a definite position and momentum.

options.label: B
options.text: The principle that the position and momentum of a particle can't be measured at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle that particles can be measured with infinite precision.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle that particles can't be measured at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is entanglement in quantum physics?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenomenon where two particles are connected and can influence each other's behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: The phenomenon where two particles are separate and can't influence each other's behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: The phenomenon where two particles are identical and can't be distinguished from each other.

options.label: D
options.text: The phenomenon where two particles are different and can be easily distinguished from each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in teleporting large objects?

options.label: A
options.text: The energy needed to teleport the object.

options.label: B
options.text: The complexity of measuring the quantum states of the object's atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of light limit for transmitting information.

multiple-choice.question: What are the philosophical implications of quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: It challenges our understanding of space and time.

options.label: B
options.text: It reveals new ways to influence the fragility of quantum information.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that objects can be transported across space instantly.

options.label: D
options.text: It proves that information can't be transmitted across space.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a well-established technology that can be used for practical applications.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a developing technology that can be used for research purposes.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a theoretical concept that is still being researched.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a phenomenon that has been observed in experiments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential future of quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be used for practical applications in the near future.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be used for research purposes in the near future.

options.label: C
options.text: It will be a major breakthrough in the next 100 years.

options.label: D
options.text: It will be a major breakthrough in the next 10,000 years.

title: Can you find the next number in this sequence? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What type of sequence is the "look and say" sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: A sequence that relies on mathematical properties of the numbers themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: A sequence that relies on the notation of the numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: A sequence that relies on random patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: A sequence that relies on linear patterns.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematician who first analyzed the look and say sequence?
What is Conway's Constant, and what is its approximate value?

options.label: A
options.text: The constant that represents the ratio between the amount of digits in two consecutive terms, equal to 1.2.

options.label: B
options.text: The constant that represents the ratio between the amount of digits in two consecutive terms, equal to 1.3.

options.label: C
options.text: The constant that represents the ratio between the amount of digits in two consecutive terms, equal to 1.5.

options.label: D
options.text: The constant that represents the ratio between the amount of digits in two consecutive terms, equal to 2.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the data compression technique that is based on a similar concept to the look and say sequence?
What is the name of the two extra elements in the look and say sequence that can end with any digit of 4 or greater?

options.label: B
options.text: The sequence that consists of only digits 1 and 2

options.label: C
options.text: The sequence that consists of only digits 1, 2, and 3

options.label: D
options.text: The sequence that can end with any digit of 4 or greater

multiple-choice.question: How many combinations of digits does Conway identify in the look and say sequence?
What is the approximate increase in the number of digits in the look and say sequence with every step?
What is the name of the concept that is used to describe the way the look and say sequence grows?
What is the name of the mathematician who first noted that the look and say sequence has some interesting properties?
What is the approximate number of elements in the look and say sequence that are composed only of digits 1, 2, and 3?

title: How does fracking work? - Mia Nacamulli

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of natural gas that is extracted through hydraulic fracturing (fracking)?

options.label: B
options.text: To pump fracking fluid into the well

options.label: C
options.text: To create a series of small holes in the shale rock

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated impact of methane leaks during the fracking process on greenhouse gas emissions?

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern regarding the long-term effects of fracking?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How do drugs affect the brain? - Sara Garofalo

multiple-choice.question: What must a drug do before it can reach the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: It must be absorbed by the digestive system and reach the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the blood-brain barrier?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow all substances to pass through to the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep potentially dangerous substances out of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main ways in which neurotransmitters work in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They can either excite or inhibit the receiving neuron.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only excite the receiving neuron.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only inhibit the receiving neuron.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only produce new neurons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of common antidepressants, like SSRIs?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase the reabsorption of serotonin.

options.label: B
options.text: They decrease the production of serotonin.

options.label: C
options.text: They stop the reabsorption of serotonin, effectively pushing more of it into the neural network.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no effect on serotonin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of painkillers, like morphine?

options.label: A
options.text: They decrease the levels of serotonin and noradrenaline.

options.label: B
options.text: They increase the levels of serotonin and noradrenaline, which regulate energy, arousal, alertness, and pleasure.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on serotonin and noradrenaline.

options.label: D
options.text: They decrease the production of GABA.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of tranquilizers?

options.label: A
options.text: They decrease the production of GABA.

options.label: B
options.text: They increase the production of GABA to inhibit neural activity.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on GABA.

options.label: D
options.text: They increase the production of serotonin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of crystal meth, an amphetamine?

options.label: A
options.text: It blocks the release of dopamine and serotonin.

options.label: B
options.text: It induces a long-lasting release of dopamine, a neurotransmitter linked with the perception of reward and pleasure.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on dopamine and serotonin.

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases the levels of dopamine and serotonin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of cocaine?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the reabsorption of dopamine and serotonin.

options.label: B
options.text: It blocks the reuptake of dopamine and serotonin, pushing more into the network.

title: Why don't perpetual motion machines ever work? - Netta Schramm

multiple-choice.question: Who sketched a design for a wheel containing curved reservoirs of mercury, which was one of the earliest designs for a perpetual motion machine?
What is the first law of thermodynamics?

options.label: A
options.text: Energy can be created or destroyed.

options.label: B
options.text: Energy can't be created or destroyed, but can be converted from one form to another.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy can be transferred from one place to another.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy can't be created or destroyed, and the total energy of a closed system remains constant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with Bhaskara's over-balanced wheel design?

options.label: C
options.text: The moving parts shift the center of mass downward below the axle, causing the wheel to swing back and forth like a pendulum.

multiple-choice.question: What is capillary action, and how did Robert Boyle propose it could be used in a perpetual motion machine?

options.label: A
options.text: Capillary action is the attraction between liquids and surfaces that pulls water through thin tubes, and Boyle proposed it could be used to draw water up a bowl and prevent it from falling back in.

options.label: B
options.text: Capillary action is the attraction between liquids and surfaces that pushes water through thin tubes, and Boyle proposed it could be used to push water down a bowl and prevent it from rising back up.

options.label: C
options.text: Capillary action is the attraction between liquids and surfaces that pulls water through thick tubes, and Boyle proposed it could be used to draw water up a bowl and prevent it from falling back in.

options.label: D
options.text: Capillary action is the attraction between liquids and surfaces that pushes water through thick tubes, and Boyle proposed it could be used to push water down a bowl and prevent it from rising back up.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second law of thermodynamics, and how does it relate to perpetual motion machines?

options.label: A
options.text: The second law of thermodynamics states that energy tends to concentrate and become more organized, and it would allow perpetual motion machines to work.

options.label: B
options.text: The second law of thermodynamics states that energy tends to spread out and become less organized, and it would prevent perpetual motion machines from working.

options.label: C
options.text: The second law of thermodynamics states that energy tends to stay the same, and it would allow perpetual motion machines to work.

options.label: D
options.text: The second law of thermodynamics states that energy tends to change from one form to another, and it would prevent perpetual motion machines from working.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why perpetual motion machines have not been successful?

options.label: C
options.text: They violate the first law of thermodynamics.

options.label: D
options.text: They violate the second law of thermodynamics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the first law of thermodynamics and perpetual motion machines?

options.label: A
options.text: The first law of thermodynamics allows perpetual motion machines to work.

options.label: B
options.text: The first law of thermodynamics prevents perpetual motion machines from working.

options.label: C
options.text: The first law of thermodynamics has no relationship to perpetual motion machines.

options.label: D
options.text: The first law of thermodynamics is a necessary condition for perpetual motion machines to work.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with the idea of a self-watering pot as a perpetual motion machine?

options.label: C
options.text: The capillary action would prevent the water from falling back into the bowl.

options.label: D
options.text: The pot would be too heavy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between friction and perpetual motion machines?

options.label: A
options.text: Friction is necessary for perpetual motion machines to work.

options.label: B
options.text: Friction prevents perpetual motion machines from working.

options.label: C
options.text: Friction has no relationship to perpetual motion machines.

options.label: D
options.text: Friction is a necessary condition for perpetual motion machines to work.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why perpetual motion machines are still being researched and developed?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they may still be possible in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not worth the effort.
